Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I now understand what media truly is, where I didn't have a clear idea before. I can see how everything ties into media.
I actually learned something about media and media studies.
I learned a lot about media and the meaning behind it. I greatly expanded my views on media as a result of this course.
I gained more knowledge of different topics such as systems theories and was able to read a lot of thought-provoking essays.
What media means, how it influences our lives.
I gained a broad understanding of the history of media studies and its major themes. I learned how to evaluate works of media within those contexts.

This course redefined the definition of media for me, and I learned a lot about media theory that I didnt originally know in the first place. It made me think deeply about the way media influences our society and our everyday lives.
I learn more about the influence of media in society and its influence on culture. I read a lot of theorists that I might not have otherwise been exposed to.
I learned about different ways to understand and classify media. I learned about the role of media in society and how it has been perceived; I also read and watched many interesting texts.
I developed a better sense of what media studies can entail.

I had no idea what Media Studies is before this class, and now I kind of get it- which is an accomplishment because it's pretty loose and complicated. I really enjoyed the lectures, which incorporated a lot of recognizable, popular media to make the course more engaging and understandable. The readings were diverse and exposed me to a lot of important scholarship applicable beyond media studies.
This is a great course that teaches you to think about things you never thought about! I had no idea what media was before starting the course; now I do.
Broad range of readings and several documentaries, from Plato to Noam Chomsky. Great overview of the history of media with clear definitions of the most important concepts.
This course was a great introduction to media theory that comprehensively explored our definitions of media and the way that it affects our lives today.
I learned how to understand media in context of the world that surrounds it  politically, culturally, and through art.
I learned a lot about media
world view completely changed. analytical and comprehension skills about how to see the world through the lens of llangauge and media.
I found the class fascinating, but I think it should be taught seminar-style. I would have been even more engaged if it had been taught in small groups.
Some of the topics were slightly confusing with the many layers to everything being discussed. The topics were very interesting.

Strengths- very interesting, cool prof
weaknesses- a little far-fetched sometimes, lots of readings

Especially towards the beginning of the course, it was sometimes hard to grasp the broader themes - to understand how certain texts fit into the larger discipline. 

However, the individual texts on the syllabus were very interesting, and Professor Williams is a very dynamic lecturer who always made interesting connections between the texts and drew them back in to their context.

I think the readings for this course should be a bit less dense or a preface of the reading should be given before it is read. On top of this, if for all section meetings, there was a discussion question sent out prior to, it would be easier to engage.

Strengths: interesting readings and videos! Lecture content was great. I felt like I was acquiring all sorts of intriguing knowledge during every class.
Weaknesses: wasn't a fan of all the theory texts
I think this course is just too broad to actually be that useful. Some of the readings are pretty interesting though, and Professor Williams does have real enthusiasm for the material.
Great lectures and readings. Could have used more instruction to help unpack difficult readings.

Professor Williams is an incredible lecturer. Unfortunately (or fortunately?), this means you almost shouldn't do the readings because a) they're often very dense and theory heavy and b) Professor Williams will explain them in a way that is both understandable and exciting the next day. I was lucky enough to also have Prof. Williams as my section leader, which I think really increased my enjoyment of the class.

Strength: diversity of course reading in terms of form
Weakness: general inaccessibility of readings, not clarified by lecture
Be careful in choosing your TA section, it might change your opinion of the course to the worst, as the teacher is simply fantastic.

The course is structured very well, progressing from word to image to machine and then finally system. I liked that the sources we engaged with came from a variety of backgrounds and forms and helped to illustrate the course themes. The assignments were interesting and grading was very fair.

Had a lot of similar course materials to Professor William's other seminars so I found myself repeating readings. Also, the Mulvey reading is in Film 150, another required course for the major, so everyone taking the course for credit within the major would've presumably repeated that reading.
I would highly recommend this class if they want a writing credit that is not extremely overbearing, but does want something that keeps their brain working.

This was a very fun course, learned a lot about a lot of stuff, you can easily get by without doing the readings. Go to class, pay attention and take notes, you won't have to do any reading. The exams are very straightforward and not hard at all. You will enjoy this course. Also, as a WR credit, I wrote less than 10 pages throughout the semester. This class is a diamond in the rough.
Yes, this course covers a lot of interesting topics and makes you look deeper at most media.
I would recommend it to anyone interested in the topics discussed. I think it would be a hard class to just walk into if the student has little interest in the topic.
Yes! It was so interesting and thought-provoking. Definitely would recommend to another student!

Yes, definitely take this class. It's a lot different from the usual writing courses at Yale but there is plenty of interesting information you can learn in this class. It will change how you see media forever.

I would recommend this course because it offers a broad base that is helpful for more advanced media studies classes. I think it would be a good complement for any humanities student, or even a STEM student (Computer Science especially) who's interested in how technology influences communication and art.

Yes, I think it facilitates a very different and new type of thinking and also is good for people outside of the film major who want to learn about media theory and theory surrounding society in general.
I don't think this course was interesting enough to recommend to other students. I would only take it as a requirement.
Yes, because the lectures were great and the workload was manageable, but I would warn them that it's pretty heavy on the theory

I was so resentful about being forced to take this class for my major that I checked out of it immediately. That being said, if its not required for you, Id skip it. The class is too broad to be all that useful I think, although some of the readings are pretty interesting.

prof williams is great. really knowledgeable on a lot of subjects, you learn a lot of cool things that are relevant to your life in this course. its an easy writing credit. i would definitely recommend
It's a great leminar. Yes, it's required for the film major, but it's a great writing credit that all majors should consider taking because the content and presentation is really interesting!
Yes! Great course, especially as an introduction to BIG IDEAS.
If they had to fulfill the film major, yes. Otherwise, no.
Would certainly recommend, even if you are not English or Film and Media. It is wonderful for common intelligence and broader outlook.
Yes. This is a great course with knowledge that is relevant to all of us. Lectures are engaging, readings are interesting and assessments are very fair, sometimes even enjoyable.

Yes  its a really great view into the world of media, but its more theoretical, so we examine many texts that are more difficult to unravel. Sections were really helpful to seeing the way that different themes of word, image and system coalesce.
This course got me thinking a lot, so if you're into thinking about the world and hypotheticals, this si the class for you.
YES - incredibly interetsing but only take with robbie williams. hes amazing. course is so good.
